meta.title: Coronavirus

meta.name: DESCRIPTION
meta.content: The coronavirus has many people feeling distressed. This is very normal in times of crisis. You can manage these feelings and try to keep yourself healthy by taking some simple steps as shown in the many resources below.

li.a: For Deaf and Hard of Hearing
About Mental Health and Addiction Treatment

td.style: width: 60%; white-space: nowrap; text-align: left; vertical-align: middle;

h5.strong: Visit coronavirus.ohio.gov or call 1-833-4-ASK-ODH for answers.

div.p: The coronavirus has many people feeling distressed. This is very normal in times of crisis. You can manage these feelings and try to keep yourself healthy by taking some simple steps as shown in the many resources below.

li.a: Message to Community Partners from OhioMHAS Director Lori Criss
Ohio Department of Health Call Center

div.div: Direct your behavioral health questions to the following:

li.a: Licensure and Certification COVID-19 Waiver Process
Licensure and Certification COVID-19 Waiver Request
Addressing Alcohol Withdrawal and AUD Treatment

ul.li: Clinician Outreach and Communication Activity—resources for healthcare providers
COCA RSS Feed—subscribe to be notified of conference calls, updates, and CDC guidance for health providers

Crisis & Emergency Risk Communication Training—training program that draws from lessons learned during public health emergencies, and incorporates best practices from the fields of risk and crisis communication

li.a: Disaster Planning Handbook for Behavioral Health Treatment Programs
Emergency Responders: Tips for taking care of yourself
Free App to Support People in Recovery During COVID-19 Outbreak
Funding for BH Services via Telehealth
Guidance to recovery housing operators and residential care facilities

ul.li: Guidance from OhioMHAS for Opioid Treatment Programs - UPDATED

li.a: Guidance for In-Home Visitation and Screening of Youth and Visitors to Offices, Facilities and Programs
Information from the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI)
Medical Clearance for Psychiatric Hospitalization-Considerations with the COVID-19 Pandemic Emergency
Medicare Telemedicine Health Care Provider Fact Sheet
National Institute of Mental Health - Coping with Coronavirus Stress
OhioMHAS State-operated Hospital Patient Screening Criteria
Psychological Effects of Quarantine for Leaders
Psychological Effects of Quarantine for Providers
Sustaining Well-being of Health Care Professionals
Training and Technical Assistance Related to COVID-19
Update for Project DAWN/Community Naloxone Distribution
Wallet Card for Coping with Disaster
What Supportive Housing Providers Need to Know
Guidance to Recovery Housing Operators and Residential Care Facilities
Guidance for In-Home Visitation and Screening of Youth and Visitors to Offices, Facilities and Programs
Medical Clearance for Psychiatric Hospitalization-Considerations with the COVID-19 Pandemic Emergency
Psychological Effects of Quarantine for Providers
Supporting Providers in Group Living Situations during COVID (provider flow)
Supporting Residents in Group Living Situations during COVID (resident flow)
What Supportive Housing Providers Need to Know

ul.li: Health Alert Network—CDC's primary method of sharing cleared information about urgent public health incidents with public information officers; federal, state, territorial, and local public health practitioners; clinicians; and public health laboratories

li.a: Managing Fears and Anxiety Around Coronavirus
National Institute of Mental Health - Coping with Coronavirus Stress
Wallet Card for Coping with Disaster
Wexner Medical Center - How to Talk to Your Children About Coronavirus

div.p: The Ohio Departments of Mental Health and Addiction Services (OhioMHAS) and Medicaid (ODM), in partnership with the Governor’s Office, have developed emergency rules to expand and enhance telehealth options for Ohioans and their providers. OhioMHAS’s emergency rule creates additional flexibilities in the agency’s regulations governing interactive videoconferencing. ODM’s emergency rule creates a new Medicaid telehealth rule that governs reimbursement policies for Medicaid providers rendering services through telehealth.

ODM and OhioMHAS are implementing these emergency rules to expand access to medical and behavioral health services using telehealth. This action is being taken to give health care providers maximum flexibility as they shift as many services as possible away from in-person visits. In addition to increasing access to care, these rules seek to also reduce pressure on Ohio hospitals. The goal of the emergency rule package is to dramatically increase regulatory flexibility so medical and behavioral health providers can offer health care services to Ohioans remotely, thereby increasing access to care, reducing pressure on our hospital systems, and reducing unnecessary patient traffic in waiting rooms during the COVID-19 emergency.

The rules also enable practitioners to more efficiently manage increasing patient inquiries and health care demands while maintaining recommended social distancing protocols designed to protect healthcare workers.

li.a: TBD Group Hourly and Per Diem Services Added to BH Services Provided via Telehealth

p.strong: Find Substance Use Disorder and Mental Health Treatment

br.br:
1-800-846-8517 TTY
Text "TalkWithUs" to 66746
Spanish-speakers: Text "Hablanos" to 66746
Available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, year-round

div.p: For more information and downloads from the Ohio Department of Health, visit coronavirus.ohio.gov.

br.br: Open 7 days a week from 9:00 am to 8:00 pm

div.p: The images below are free for any entity to use.
